name: init-script-rcS-no-nvram-access
description: No access to NVRAM or environment variables was found in the etc/init.d/rcS startup script. The script primarily performs system initialization tasks such as mounting filesystems, creating directories, setting kernel parameters, and loading kernel modules.

name: env_get-http_rpm_auth_main-pwd
notes: Although no direct getenv calls were found, a similar functionality was implemented through the custom function http_parser_getEnv. It is recommended to further analyze the implementation details of this function to assess its security.

name: env_get-http_rpm_auth_main-name
description: The REDACTED_PASSWORD_PLACEHOLDER variable lacks sufficient validation and could be exploited for information disclosure or identity spoofing. This variable is retrieved via the http_parser_getEnv function.
notes: Although no direct getenv call was found, similar functionality was implemented through the custom function http_parser_getEnv.

name: env_get-http_rpm_log_main-clr
description: Controls the log clearing function, has undergone basic validation, and poses a low risk. This variable is obtained through the http_parser_getEnv function.
notes: Although no direct getenv calls were found, similar functionality was achieved through the custom function http_parser_getEnv.

name: env_get-http_rpm_lanMac-num
description: Controls the number of loop iterations with a range checking mechanism. This variable is obtained via the http_parser_getEnv function.
notes: Although no direct getenv call was found, similar functionality was implemented through the custom function http_parser_getEnv.

name: env_set-dropbearmulti-putenv
description: The putenv function call was found in the SSH server binary (dropbearmulti), but no direct getenv calls were located. This indicates the program primarily sets environment variables via putenv rather than reading them. No evident environment variable read operations were detected, thus posing no direct security risk.
notes: Although the putenv call was detected, there is no evidence indicating that the program reads sensitive environment variables. It is recommended to further analyze how the program utilizes the set environment variables.

name: env-access-cwmp-negative
description: No direct environment variable access points (such as getenv) or NVRAM-related operations were found in the TR-069 client binary (cwmp). This suggests that the program may not directly handle these configuration access mechanisms or obtains configuration data through other indirect means.
notes: It is recommended that subsequent analysis focus on other configuration access mechanisms of the program, such as obtaining configuration data through IPC or other inter-process communication methods.

name: config-analysis-default_config.xml-negative
description: Analysis of the etc/default_config.xml file did not reveal any recognizable NVRAM or environment variable references. The file content appears to be in binary or encoded format, with no detection of common environment variable syntax patterns.
notes: The file is not in plain text format, making deeper analysis impossible. Further verification may require decoding or reverse engineering of the binary file.
